pr_title: Reduce client to database calls for New Order inserts and selects

timeline.bodyText: might be cleaner to use something like this: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Formatter.html
timeline.author: robertsami

timeline.message:
Reducing calls from the client to the Database for New Order Transaction.

Summary:
This change involves:
1. Batching the select for entries in `Item` into 1 statement.
2. Batching the select for entries in `Stock` into 1 statement.
3. Batching the update of all the entries in `Stock` using a PgSql
   procedure.
4. Batching the insert for all entries into `OrderLine`.

Reviewers:
Karthik, Mihnea

timeline.bodyText:
move this into the com.oltpbenchmark block.
Also any reason for reordering these import blocks?
I think putting the more fundamental imports (e.g. java.util) first, and then the local-package imports (e.g. com.oltpbenchmark) is fairly common.
timeline.author: m-iancu

timeline.bodyText: something looks odd about indentation above (e.g. some lines not being changed, for others the highlighted spaces size&location differ)? If we are changing that can you double-check it is consistent. But probably easier to keep the existing style (or otherwise other files will now differ from the ones changed here).
timeline.author: m-iancu
m-iancu

timeline.bodyText: Add a comment here explaining how these are handled below.
timeline.author: m-iancu

timeline.bodyText:
nit: maybe add a comment/new-line before this line too (to separate the two kinds of statements now).
Also maybe mention how are we getting away with just having one prepared statement here (because they are cached somewhere else and this is just the current one)?
timeline.author: m-iancu
m-iancu

replies.bodyText:
Done.
Back in nutanix single letter variables were not allowed and we used 'ii' and 'jj' as the index variables. Hence the habit.

timeline.message:
Reduce client to database calls for New Order Inserts and Selects.

Summary:
This change involves:
1. Batching the select for entries in `Item` into 1 statement using the
   'IN' predicate.
2. Batching the select for entries in `Stock` into 1 statement using the
   'IN' predicate.
3. Batching the insert for all entries into `OrderLine` using the
   multirow VALUES syntax.

Reviewers:
Karthik, Mihnea
